articles.headline: No Pecan Pie? Thank China, Rain and Pigs
articles.snippet: A rare collision of ill-timed rain, wild animals, and a growing love affair between China and the pecan has led to the worst supply in years, and grocery store prices are up by about 30 percent.
articles.abstract: A rare collision of ill-timed rain, wild animals, and a growing love affair between China and the pecan has led to the worst supply in years, and grocery store prices are up by about 30 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: OCILLA, Ga. — It is a meager holiday in the pecan groves of the South, and the pain is stretching to kitchens across the country.

articles.headline: Merger of American and US Airways Is Waved Ahead
articles.snippet: A federal bankruptcy judge approved American’s reorganization plan, which means the carrier’s proposed merger with US Airways can proceed.
articles.abstract: A federal bankruptcy judge approved American’s reorganization plan, which means the carrier’s proposed merger with US Airways can proceed.
articles.lead_paragraph: With American Airlines’ exit from bankruptcy on Wednesday, the grunt work of merging the airline with US Airways can begin and it will most likely be a long-haul affair, analysts said.

articles.headline: Apple’s Pages, Going the Distance With Word
articles.snippet: To point out the vast improvement in the new version of Pages, we offer a three-round comparison bout between it and Word.
articles.abstract: To point out the vast improvement in the new version of Pages, we offer a three-round comparison bout between it and Word.
articles.lead_paragraph: My mother is not anti-Apple. She owns a Mac and an older iPad, but has always been perfectly satisfied with her trusty copy of Microsoft Word. “That’s what everyone uses,” she says.

articles.headline: Lighting Up the Lawn With 16 Million Colors
articles.snippet: New computerized systems and smartphone apps can make Christmas much more than incandescent lights and inflatable snowmen.
articles.abstract: New computerized systems and smartphone apps can make Christmas much more than incandescent lights and inflatable snowmen.
articles.lead_paragraph: It starts with an innocent string of incandescent holiday lights around a porch window, maybe a plastic caroler or two on the front lawn.
articles.byline: By Roxie Hammill and Mike Hendricks

articles.headline: Online Health Law Sign-Up Is Delayed for Small Business
articles.snippet: In yet another setback for the rollout of the health care law, the Obama administration announced that the online exchange for small businesses would not be available until next November.
articles.abstract: In yet another setback for the rollout of the health care law, the Obama administration announced that the online exchange for small businesses would not be available until next November.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Wednesday announced a one-year delay in a major element of the new health care law that would allow small businesses to buy insurance online for their employees through the new federal marketplace.

articles.headline: Hospital Studies Link Heart Device to Clots
articles.snippet: Patients with the HeartMate II, an implant used to treat advanced heart failure, are suffering clots at nearly four times the rate they used to, data shows.
articles.abstract: Patients with the HeartMate II, an implant used to treat advanced heart failure, are suffering clots at nearly four times the rate they used to, data shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: Doctors at the Cleveland Clinic began to suspect in 2012 that something might be wrong with a high-tech implant used to treat patients with advanced heart failure like former Vice President Dick Cheney.

articles.headline: Analyst Says SAC Trader Sought ‘Edgy’ Information
articles.snippet: Jon Horvath, the federal government’s star witness in an insider trading case, said his former boss, Michael S. Steinberg, wanted him to cross a legal line.
articles.abstract: Jon Horvath, the federal government’s star witness in an insider trading case, said his former boss, Michael S. Steinberg, wanted him to cross a legal line.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jon Horvath needed to step up his game at SAC Capital Advisors.

articles.headline: Alaska Democrats See a Palin Legacy They Can Like
articles.snippet: Efforts to repeal a new, more lenient tax law on oil profits in Alaska are stirring up a strange political cocktail, in which Democrats find themselves backing Sarah Palin.
articles.abstract: Efforts to repeal a new, more lenient tax law on oil profits in Alaska are stirring up a strange political cocktail, in which Democrats find themselves backing Sarah Palin.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANCHORAGE — For many Alaskans, Sarah Palin is a figure in the rearview mirror, the memories of her time as governor obscured and distorted by the national spotlight she stepped into as Republican vice-presidential candidate, pundit and Tea Party darling. And often as not the memories come with a grumble anyway, since her shooting-star career mostly took off after leaving the state.

articles.headline: Secret Weapon in Mall Battle: Parking Apps
articles.snippet: Smartphone apps are one way malls and shopping districts are trying to make parking easier to lure customers away from their computers and back into the realm of brick-and-mortar stores.
articles.abstract: Smartphone apps are one way malls and shopping districts are trying to make parking easier to lure customers away from their computers and back into the realm of brick-and-mortar stores.
articles.lead_paragraph: Phoebe Scott of Orange County, Calif., has a new routine before heading to the mall.

articles.headline: The Hard Charger at Obama’s Side Has His Hands Full
articles.snippet: Denis McDonough finds himself fixing the health care debacle he did not see coming, preparing for the next spending showdown with Congress and trying to rescue an imperiled presidency.
articles.abstract: Denis McDonough finds himself fixing the health care debacle he did not see coming, preparing for the next spending showdown with Congress and trying to rescue an imperiled presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Denis McDonough was pacing the path on the South Lawn of the White House one day this fall, ruminating on the challenges of a second term for his boss, President Obama. Mr. McDonough, the White House chief of staff, likes to stroll outside from time to time. It helps clear his head when he has a lot on his mind.
